“An Impotent Veracity for Desultory Information”:Reading Moore’s Miscellaneous Notebook, 1930-1943
Jeff Westover
Several passages in a reading notebook Marianne Moore maintained from 1930 to 1943 (VII.2.2) attest to Moore’s focus on the limitations on human knowledge, limitations based on the complexity and scale of the cosmos, theological ideas about human nature, and perhaps even the contingent nature of taxonomies. For example, in an article about Roger and Francis Bacon in Scientific Monthly by Sanford Fernando, a physicist who taught at Stanford, Moore singles out the following passage about the medieval scholar Roger Bacon’s view of “the fallibility of human reason”:
it is certain that never, before God is seen face to face, shall a man know anything with final certainty. It is impossible therefore for a man to attain perfect knowledge in this life, & it is exceedingly difficult for him to attain perfect truth, & he is very prone & disposed toward whatever is false & empty; wherefore man ought not to boast of his knowledge. (image 00220 verso and recto)
This excerpt squares with a traditional Christian emphasis on humility as a virtue. But it appears in a popular article by a professional scientist who singles out Bacon for his emphasis on the importance of evidence-based reasoning. At the same time that Moore demonstrates her appetite for learning about a variety of topics, she testifies to her belief about the limits to human knowledge in such passages. This conflicting attitude toward knowing things seems in keeping with Moore’s poetic values of intensive detail, energetic syntax, and restraint. In the poems of the thirties (the ones most relevant to the notebook), as in the earlier poems “The Octopus” and “Marriage,” she sometimes offers a bewildering array of images and ideas. This can arouse a kind of exhilaration in the reader, but it also points to the challenges of sorting out significance. It may also caution readers to acknowledge the complexity, diversity, and contradictory aspects of experience in order to avoid oversimplifying them. The notebook’s diversity of subjects, together with such caution about the limits of knowledge, provides a model for considering the central tension in her poems between a voracious “capacity for fact” (as Moore puts it in “The Octopus”) and a reverent restraint in the face of imperfect human wisdom.
